page.title: 14The Droitwich Canal
page.content: The canal ran from its junction with the Worcester and Birmingham Canal at Hanbury, through Droitwich and into the River Severn at Hawford. It was built following an Act of Parliament in 1768 to carry salt from Droitwich down to the Severn and thence to the port of Bristol. The cost of building the canal was Â£23,500 . It runs sided by side with the River Salwarpe for some 6.75 miles with eight locks. The boats were 64 feet by 14.5 feet. The salt industry declined from 1860 onwards and with it, the canal. A proposal to turn the canal into a railway was resisted and it fell into disuse in the mid 1920's. It was closed by an Act of Abandonment in 1939. In 1973 a charitable group consisting of volunteers started to restore the canal. The Droitwich Canal Trust has much work left to do.
